response.answer_text: To make this easier, let’s just use a general case [math]f(x) = x^n e^x[/math] [math]f’(x) = n x^{n-1}e^x + x^n e^x = n x^{n-1}e^x + f(x)[/math] [math]f’’(x) = n(n-1)x^{n-2}e^x +n x^{n-1} e^x + f’(x) [/math] Ok so you can see how factors are coming down as you differentiate and include terms in x and and the original function. Since you only need the value at x=0, you can focus directly on the term where the power becomes 0 (i.e. the constant). All other terms include an x with power of at least 1, so they will equate to 0 when you include it. You don’t actually need to calculate the final derivative (which is very laborious). All you need is to see the pattern and extrapolate. The final term with power of 0 would be [math]n(n-1)(n-2)…(n-(k-1)) = k! \binom{n}{k} = 9![/math] (where n = 9 and k=9) Or alternatively note when you differentiate once you get a 9, differentiate twice, 9 x 8, three times 9 x 8 x 7, etc. This is [math]\frac{n!}{(n-k)!}[/math] Differentiate 9 times and you get [math]\frac{9!}{(9–9)!} = 9![/math]

The answer is 9! Let’s look at the first two derivatives of (x^9)(e^x): 1st derivative: 9 x^8 e^x + x^9 e^x 2nd derivative: (9)(8) x^7 e^x + 9 x^8 e^x + 9 x^8 e^x + x^9 e^x Carrying this to the 9th derivative, you can see that the leftmost term becomes 9! e^x and the other terms are still multiplied by a power of x. So at x=0, we’re left with 9! e^0 = 9!(1) = 9!
